@JaBogen First, I don't think that has correlation to whether they want to be in class or not.
Second, naturally, I take the much more cynical view that this, like most protests, is about feeling good and spending time with like-minded friends.
@JaBogen What percentage of teenagers do you think would rather hang out with their friends than be in school? Over/under 80%?
@JaBogen Actually, there's a model for that — anti-Vietnam college students scheduled "teach ins" to inform their more apathetic classmates about the flaws of American engagement in Indochina.

@JaBogen Avoiding something you don't want to do, like go to class, is the laziest form of protesting. If they somehow went to school more it would actually mean they care about the underlying concern.
High school students protesting by leaving class is like me protesting by going to a bar. https://t.co/QhVQPxJFAb

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith And I don't think it's a wave election if the party loses seats in the stronger chamber. Whether fair or not, the constitutional architecture of our politics makes it hard to be competitive if your message alienates the voters who live in most states.
@raylehmann @DCameronSmith Elections are the only mark-to-market indicator in politics, so we'll find out soon enough.
@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I think that's limited to upscale, educated white women, aka House of Representative map voters.
@raylehmann @DCameronSmith At least anecdotally, Republicans I know (in liberal Massachusetts) are enraged by this as much as Democrats were enraged by Trump's election and BK's confirmation.

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I think you're really underestimating how much, regardless of the merits of the position, Republicans believe BK was a victim of character assassination by both cynical Democratic operatives and the insane Feminazis. I could be in a bubble of politically engaged people, but...

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I think in both states base mobilization is enough for the GOP candidate to win, even if they lose the lion's share of swing voters. That's why I think Kavanaugh will end up being a boon in the Senate.
@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I'm skeptical the electorate HH is facing is that different from the one faced by Donnelly, CMC, and other Trump-state Dems. Do think Florida is a different story.
@JaBogen You have a nickname, it's Jules. Because I use and have impeccable taste in all things, it's the only option.

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I've always been skeptical of a "two track" outcome where Dems win the House but lose more than one Senate seat. That doesn't fit with my view of modern midterms as fundamentally nationalized referendums on the party in power. I'm now a lot more comfortable accepting that CW.
RT @RadioFreeTom: This is a terrible response, because it cedes that courts are now our lawmaking bodies, and then argues for defying those…

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith Maybe it's just static and there will be regression to the mean next week, but I'm much more confident in predicting a split-chamber result (which I've been leery of given the fundamentals of modern partisan politics) than I was before Kavanaugh.

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I agree re: Manchin. I just also think there's been a demonstrable increase in Republican partisan engagement, which all but rules out a 2010-style wave, which requires winning swing voters plus a turnout differential to win in unfriendly territory.
@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I don't think the red-state Senate movement and small dollar donation surge occurred independent of the Kavanaugh hearings.

@raylehmann @DCameronSmith I'm skeptical that backlash will extend beyond upscale, educated suburban women who are concentrated in blue-State CDs. It'll take an election, the only mark-to-market indicator in politics, to find out, but right now this looks like a big short-term and long-term GOP win.
